nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation-based teacher evaluation can produce lasting improvements in teacher effectiveness (skill, effort, or both) that increase student achievement after the evaluation period

Background: teachers vary widely in effectiveness, but common observable personnel characteristics (graduate degree, experience beyond early years) poorly predict productivity, motivating performance evaluation

Research design: quasi-experimental analysis using phased-in timing of Cincinnati Public Schools Teacher Evaluation System (TES) for mid-career math teachers, comparing within-teacher performance before, during, and after evaluation

TES program description: year-long observation-based evaluation with three peer observations and one administrator observation, rubric based on Danielson framework, written feedback after observations, final summative scores in four domains, evaluators trained for interrater reliability

Analysis sample and identification: fourth–eighth grade math teachers hired 1993–1999 evaluated 2003–2010 due to phase-in schedule; sample choice reduces correlation between evaluation timing and contemporaneous class assignment and allows counterfactual pre-evaluation performance

Empirical strategy: teacher fixed effects regressions of student standardized math scores controlling for grade-by-year fixed effects, student covariates and prior achievement, and a capped quadratic in teacher experience; parameterize treatment as indicators for evaluation year and post-evaluation years

Main result: students taught by a teacher after that teacher underwent TES score about 0.112 standard deviations higher in math compared to students taught by the same teacher before evaluation (statistically significant)
During-evaluation result: students taught during the TES evaluation year show modestly higher math scores (point estimate ~0.052 SD) but this increase is not consistently statistically significant

Heterogeneity: postevaluation gains are larger for teachers with low preevaluation test-score value-added, for teachers with low TES rubric scores, and for teachers whose TES scores improved most during the evaluation year

Event-study and balance checks: year-by-year indicators show no preexisting upward trend in teacher performance prior to evaluation; observable student and teacher covariates do not vary systematically with evaluation timing

Robustness to alternative specifications: results persist when using scheduled evaluation year (phase-in) instead of actual year and in 2SLS instrumenting actual timing with scheduled timing; results robust to alternative experience controls and sample restrictions

Attrition analysis: modest attrition exists but (i) rates are similar to district norms, (ii) observable attrition is not significantly correlated with evaluation timing, and (iii) restricting to teachers observed before and after evaluation or weighting by inverse persistence probability yields similar postevaluation gains

Proposed mechanism: evaluation provides individualized, credible performance information via rubric scoring, written feedback, peer evaluators, and self-reflection opportunities, enabling teachers to learn and adopt practices or sustain higher effort that persist after evaluation
Limitation: data do not identify the precise behavioral or instructional changes causing gains, so mechanism attribution between skill acquisition versus sustained effort remains speculative

Costs and calibration: TES direct budget ~1.8–2.1 million dollars per year (~7,500 per teacher evaluated) and opportunity cost arises from using effective teachers as peer evaluators whose classes are filled by less-experienced replacements; net productivity tradeoff depends on evaluator replacement assumptions but comparison suggests program benefits can compare favorably

Conclusion: well-structured subjective evaluation systems can function as effective, nontransient professional development that raises teacher effectiveness (at least in math) and may generalize to other sectors where individualized performance information is scarce
